title: 106_s1704
content: The Act may be cited as the "Access to High Standards Act." Congress finds that many students lack academic preparation in secondary school, leading to limited job opportunities, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation in college. There is a consensus that raising academic standards and expectations is crucial for improving public education, with a focus on modeling standards after advanced placement courses. Advanced placement programs are endorsed by education leaders and almost half of all States. These programs offer 30 college-level courses, are available in almost 60% of secondary schools, and serve over 1,000,000 students. Test scores from these programs are accepted for college credit at over 3,000 colleges and universities, as well as in Germany, France, Austria, Canada, and the United Kingdom. "24 States fund programs to increase participation in advanced placement, including teacher professional development, offering courses in public schools, paying test fees, and granting academic credit for high scores. These State programs are supported by education leaders and are accepted for college credit at numerous institutions in the US and abroad." The State programs for advanced placement have shown success in raising academic standards, increasing enrollment, achievement, and minority participation. The purposes of this Act are to encourage more students to demonstrate their achievements through advanced placement exams. The Act aims to encourage students to take advanced placement exams to demonstrate their achievements, build on the benefits of the programs, and support efforts to raise academic standards at the State and local levels. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs by expanding availability, diversifying student participation, and building on existing state programs. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement courses for a diverse range of students, including low-income and disadvantaged students, as well as juniors in schools without advanced placement programs. The goal is to raise participation rates to 25% of the student population and increase the number of students benefiting from these courses. The goal is to raise participation rates to 25% of the student population and increase the numbers of students who receive advanced placement test scores for which college academic credit is awarded. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis to carry out authorized activities for a period of 3 years with annual payments. Eligible entities are defined in this section. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis to carry out authorized activities for a period of 3 years with annual payments. Eligible entities, defined as State or local educational agencies, must demonstrate a need for advanced placement programs, involve business and community organizations, and have matching funds available from State or local sources. The eligible entities must have sources to pay for activities, focus on expanding advanced placement programs in English, math, and science, and target schools with a high concentration of low-income students. An eligible entity, particularly a local educational agency serving schools with a high concentration of low-income students, can use grant funds to expand access to advanced placement programs through various activities like teacher training, course development, curriculum coordination, and supplies. The eligible entity can use grant funds for curriculum development, books, supplies, and activities related to expanding access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals. The entity must submit an application to the Secretary for the grant, and report data annually. The eligible entity receiving a grant must report annually to the Secretary on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, the number of tests taken, test scores, and demographic information of students disaggregated by various categories. The Secretary will compile and report annually to Congress on information received from eligible entities regarding students' advanced placement courses, tests, scores, and demographic details. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for online advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students. Grant funds provided under this section may be used to purchase online curriculum, train teachers on its use, or buy course materials. Local educational agencies must submit applications to the Secretary for grants. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and necessary sums for the following 4 years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. Each institution of higher education receiving Federal funds must distribute information to secondary school counselors or advanced placement coordinators regarding academic credit for advanced placement test scores. Standardization of information dissemination must occur within 4 years of the enactment of this Act. The information from paragraph (1) is shared by different departments within the institution of higher education. State and local initiatives include amendments to programs for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for upward bound projects focusing on advanced placement courses. Additionally, there are amendments to programs for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for advanced placement instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for advanced placement instruction, including professional development activities. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for advanced placement instruction in underserved communities and education technology grants. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for advanced placement instruction in underserved communities and provide education technology grants. Amendments include changes to section 3136(c) to enhance advanced placement instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for advanced placement instruction in underserved communities and provide education technology grants. Amendments include enhancing advanced placement instruction by using education technology. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "advanced placement incentive program" refers to a program providing activities and services to low-income individuals. "Advanced placement test" is an exam approved by the College Board or Secretary. "High concentration of low-income students" denotes an agency or school with a significant number of low-income students. The term "low-income individual" refers to a person who meets the criteria of being academically prepared to take an advanced placement test. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The terms "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" are also defined. The terms "secondary school" and "State educational agency" are defined in section 14101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" includes various entities within the United States and its territories.
